sub_topic: Identifying the Eulerian and Hamiltonian paths in a graph.
message_1:
Find an Eulerian path in the following undirected graph. If it does not exist, explain why not.
 
![Graph Theory Image](https://i.imgur.com/YjXTuV7.png)
message_2:
An Eulerian path is a path in a graph that visits every edge exactly once. A graph has an Eulerian path if and only if it is connected and has exactly 0 or 2 vertices of odd degree.

Let's analyze the given graph:

1. The graph is connected.
2. The degrees of the vertices are as follows:
   - A: degree 3 (odd)
   - B: degree 4 (even)
   - C: degree 3 (odd)
   - D: degree 4 (even)
   - E: degree 4 (even)
   - F: degree 4 (even)

There are exactly 2 vertices with odd degree (A and C), so an Eulerian path exists in this graph.

One possible Eulerian path is: A-B-C-D-E-F-D-C-B-A
